titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Delivered to Mr: Brazer the deed of House in Franklin-Place N: 13. and received of him the remainder of the money due for it— Deposited it in the Branch Bank.— Circuit Court of the United States commenced their Session this morning— Mr: W. E. Channing was ordained in Federal Street. Went with Caroline, but could scarcely get places— Almost suffocated with heat— Club this Evening at Mr: Amory’s.

2. Adjourned meeting of the Trustees of the Hopkins donation— The Committee gave notice that they were not yet prepared to report— Adjourned without day— A special meeting to be called by the Treasurer whenever the Committee shall be ready.— Meeting of Committee of Neponset Bridge Directors— Agreed upon a Meeting of the Directors 12. O’Clock Saturday— Attended the Circuit Court all day— Evening at home— Finished reading Love’s Labour’s Lost.

3. Attended at the Office of the Commissioners for a dividend in the case of W. Micklefield— Rest of the day, chiefly in Court. Walk’d in the Mall this Evening: Began reading to the Ladies, Kippis’s life of Captain Cook.

4. At the Commissioners Office for dividends in the cases of J. Vinall and W. Allis. Part of the Morning in Court, and heard the trial of Southack for a forged order on the President of the U. States Bank. Dined at Mr: S. Cobb’s, with Mr: Bourne our former Consul at Amsterdam. In the afternoon I went out to Quincy, with Dexter, who came in with the Chaise.

5. Heard Mr: Whitney.— Employed the leisure part of the day upon the life of Pascal— In the Evening we attended the wedding of my Cousin Susannah Adams to Mr: Darius Boardman of Boston— They were married by Mr: Whitney— I agreed to go with him to Boston to-morrow morning.

6. Came into Boston early this morning with Mr: Whitney— Attended the Circuit Court all the forenoon— Heard the close of Dr: Morse’s Sermon to the Antient and Honourable Artillery Company— Then Walk’d with them in procession to Dinner at Faneuil-Hall— Among the Company was General Pinckney— And Mr: Thacher the member of Congress; with whom I was not before acquainted— In the afternoon I went up to the State-house, with Caroline, and saw the usual ceremony, from the Senate Chamber— Continued reading to the Ladies in the Evening.

7. Attended on the Circuit Court the whole day— Much business done by them— Dined with the Judges, at Mr: George Blake’s— Short walk at the beginning of the Evening— Rest of it reading to the Ladies— Unwell.

8. Attended the Court again the whole day, in continual expectation of the case of Graves and Barnwell agt: the Marine Insurance Company— Some Depositions taken by Mr: Callender— After a short walk I return’d home in the Evening— Reminded of the Club, which I then attended at Judge Davis’s— Company thin— Dr: Prince of Salem there.

9. Mr: Graves’s Cause Continued for Depositions to be taken— Circuit Court this day adjourned— Mr: Shaw went out to Quincy, and return’d this evening— Quincy alarm’d me with the information that my Mother had been hurt by an accident the day before yesterday— Mr: G. Apthorp confirmed the fact— Shaw says she is this day better— Walk’d a short time in the Mall— And continued reading Cook’s Life.
10. Pass’d a principal part of the day at home; and the remainder at my Office— Walk in the mall, in the Evening— Read in a desultory Manner at my Office— Continued Cook’s life in the Evening.

11. Forenoon at my Office— After dinner I went out to Quincy— Found my mother very ill. Confined to her bed— I am left again to a life of idleness, and can take interest in nothing to afford me occupation—
12. Heard Mr: Whitney— Read 10. 11. 12. and 13th: of the Provincial letters— Wrote a little— Very little— Bathed at Mr: Black’s wharf this morning—

13. Return’d to Boston; with Mr: Gardner from Milton. Pass’d the day at my Office— Evening at home— Finished the first and began the second Volume of Cook’s life— In the Morning before leaving Quincy, I bathed at the wharf— And read the 14th: of the Provincial letters.— Mrs: Copp.

14. Spent the day at My Office, and the Evening at home— Reading— Harrison’s Chancery Practice— Montaigne’s Essays Vol: 5.— Plautus’s Amphytrio— And to the Ladies Cook’s life— Too desultory. I am not so much pleased with Montaigne as I expected.

15. Meeting of the Historical Society this morning, for the annual choice of Officers— Those of the last Year re-elected; excepting only that Mr: Quincy was chosen Treasurer instead of Mr: Tudor— Several Committees were appointed for various purposes— The second Volume of Judge Minot’s History is published— I read the greater part of it this afternoon— Evening partly at home— Remainder with the Club at Judge Dawes’s.

16. Met the Committee for publications of the American Academy, at their room in the State-house. And also the Committee of the Historical Society— Dr: Morse, and Mr: Townsend dined with us. Mr: Bridge spent the afternoon at my Office— Evening at home, reading Cook’s life.

17. Bunker-Hill anniversary, and military parade— Took a deposition of Thomas Holland, for the Supreme Court at New-York— With W. Sullivan— Wrote in the morning at home— Finished reading the second volume of Mr: Minot’s History, and partly reviewed it— Read in the Transactions of the Royal Society— Montaigne’s Essays, and in the Evening, Cook’s life.

18. Morning at My Office— Mr: Bridge called and pass’d an hour with me— Mr: Gardner Greene took me out with him to Vila’s at Watertown, where The Assistant fire-club dined.— We returned early in the evening to Boston; the weather being cold and drizzling— Had a fire this Evening— Finished reading the life of Captain Cook, by Dr: Kippis— Began Shakespeare’s Taming of the Shrew.

19. Heard Mr. Gray, with whom I was well satisfied— Spent the principal part of the day in writing. Walk in the Evening with Caroline in the Mall— Read further in Shakespeare.— George somewhat unwell.

20. Day at my Office.— Principally standing, for sake of health— Writing and reading— Finished the life of Florian— Wrote my brother— Read Montagne—Plautus, and in the Evening Shakespear— Finished the taming of the Shrew, and began All’s Well that ends Well.

21. Mr: Babcock at My Office— Attended with the Commissioners in the case of A. Blanchard— Employ’d the day as usual at the Office— The General Court have altered the times of holding the Supreme Court in this County, to November and March, so that I cannot be here at another session for some years— Mrs: Welsh, and Charlotte, and the Doctor called and spent an hour with us this Evening.— Read of course less than usual— But in the afternoon I read the Asinaria of Plautus. A strange picture of Grecian Manners. George measures 2 feet 9 inches 7/10
22. The heat of midsummer has overtaken us— Dr: Tufts and Mr: Boylston at my Office. Pass’d the day there, as usual— But standing— Walk’d in the Mall— Evening with the Club at Dr: Dexter’s—

23. Forenoon at My Office— The weather warm to such excess that I remained at home most of the afternoon— And read the Anlularia of Plautus.— It was the model of Moliere’s and Fielding’s Miser— There is much wit—but much coarseness— The imitations are generally esteemed superior to the originals— A great part of the humour of Plautus consists in jokes between slaves, about their mischievous tricks and their punishments— In the evening I read part of All’s Well that Ends Well.

24. Morning at my Office, but from the excessive heat of the weather did not go this afternoon. The want of rain has become a drowth— I never knew a summer to pass in this Country without it, about this season. I believe this is one of the great causes of the infertility of our Lands— I wrote a little, and read this afternoon the Captives of Plautus; which Lessing pronounces the most perfect Comedy ever written— I am sorry not to be of Lessing’s opinion— But it is better than any other I have read of Plautus— He boasts of its purity of language, sentiment and morals— With good reason, if the comparison be with himself. Yet almost all the wit of the piece, turns upon the hunger of a Parasite.— I could hardly walk this Evening— Finished reading All’s Well that Ends Well—And began the Twelfth Night.

25. The wind came round to the eastward, and the weather grew cool without rain. The grass on the Common is parch’d and yellow as December— I spent the day chiefly at home; and had no opportunity to go out to Quincy at Night— Read this afternoon the Curculio of Plautus— A Parasite again— Very hungry— Some of the wit in this play consists in the gasconades of a Soldier— Read further in Twelfth Night— I have taken a bad cold, and could therefore read but little loud.

26. A very little rain in the Night. It threatened, all this day but did not come. Heard Dr: Morse in the morning and Mr: Emerson after dinner. Walk’d early in the morning— Met Mr: Edwards in the Mall, and accompanied him for an hour— In the evening, finished reading Twelfth Night to the Ladies. Wrote but little this day; and read not much.

27. Called at the Marine Insurance Office, and heard some curious conversation on the purchase of Louisiana. An Account of which has just arrived from France. I pass’d the remainder of the day, at my Office and House; reading and writing— The Casina of Plautus— ‘Tis another old man, in love with a young girl; who gets cheated finally, something at Dr: Caius and Slender, are deceiv’d in the merry Wives of Windsor— There is a remarkable casting of lots in this play— The wit, as in all the others is low, and coarse. The language and action especially towards the close, indecent beyond expression— The worst passages however are missing from the manuscripts— I took up this morning the Satire of Juvenal, which two years ago I left unfinish’d— And translated a few verses of it.— This evening, read part of the Suspicious Husband to the Ladies; from the British Theatre Vol: 8.

28. Fire at Fort Independence on Castle Island— Forenoon principally preparing to leave my Office, which I am to give up at the close of this Month— When I came home to dinner I found the child very ill; and he continued so untill ten o’clock this Evening— An Emetic relieved him, and before midnight he appeared to be quite recovered.

29. By invitation from the board of health I accompanied them on a water-party, to Rainsford’s Island. The company, about forty persons met at the Office of the board in the Old State-House, soon after eight O’Clock this morning— Before nine we went on board the vessel at the Long wharf, and between One and two reached the island— The winds were light and adverse; and the tide served us only part of the time; but we dined on the island, and at 5 in the afternoon embarked again; we stopped about half an hour at the Castle, and saw Mrs: Freeman, the Captain’s Wife: whom I think I have seen before. She was a Duncan— The wind and tide both favoured us in coming up, and we landed soon after 8 in the Evening— Went home— Took a short walk with Mrs: Adams and Caroline— Did not go to club this Evening— The child has been this day much better than yesterday.

30. I this day gave up my Office in State-Street, which I have kept one year and an half since my return from Europe. I gave it up sooner than I should perhaps; at the request of Mr: Lowell of whom I hired it. As a summer room it is too much exposed to the heat— And as the Supreme Court is postponed untill November, I shall not have business enough, in the interval before I go to Congress, to make it worth the cost of an Office.— I attended the publishing Committee of the Academy at the State-House. From noon till 2 P.M.— In the afternoon; read the Epidicus of Plautus— His Cistellaria I had read the day before yesterday— ‘Tis very short— Not longer than a single Act of Many modern Comedies— All the plays indeed both of Terence and Plautus, are very short, and have an extreme simplicity in the plot— The Cistellaria, is the common history of a courtezan discovered to be the daughter of a free Citizen— It contains a scene of madness— Very feebly drawn. The Epidicus is one of Plautus’s best pieces, and will bear a parallel with the Captives— Tis however the same story, as most of the others— An old man cheated of his money by a slave, and a courtezan proving to be his daughter— In the evening, we finished The Suspicious Husband. I bathed this morning at the bottom of the Common.

Day. I sleep alone in my study, and rise usually at about 6. Read, write, or walk out, and lately bathe, which employs the time till 9. Breakfast. Dress. Go to Market, and thence to my Office. Attend there untill 2. Home to dinner; and return to the Office, where I read Montaigne— Since the very warm weather I have substituted my own study, where I read Plautus— Walk out, about 7. in the Evening for an hour— Return; read an hour or two to the Ladies, untill 10. Light Supper, and retire about 11. at Night, to-bed.
